questions.question: Which of the following opioids has maximum plasma protein binding capacity?
Which among the following is the most potent opioid analgesic?
questions.explanation: Sufentanil is the most potent opioid. It is 1000 times more potent than morphine.On the other hand, fentanyl is around 100 times more potent than morphine.

questions.question: Which of the following has the most rapid analgesic action?
questions.explanation: The most rapid analgesic action is achieved by remifentanil.Analgesic action (peak) is achieved within 1 to 1.5 min following intravenous administration.Analgesic action- duration for peak action:•Remifentanil: 1 to 1.5 min• Fentanyl: 5 min•Sufentanil: 5 min•Meperidine: 15 min380The rapid onset of action and the rapid recovery (within 15 min) owing to metabolism by plasmaesterases of remifentanil make it an ideal analgesic for short painful procedures.

questions.question: A middle-aged man with liver metastasis and altered LFT is posted for a surgery. What wouldbe the opioid of choice in him?
questions.explanation: Opioid of choice in patients with compromised hepatic function is remifentanil.Remifentanil is hydrolyzed by plasma and tissue esterases and hence its metabolism isindependent of hepatic function.Other opioids like fentanyl, alfentanil, and sufentanil are metabolized by the liver.

questions.question: A 48-year-old woman with CKD is scheduled for a surgery. Her serum creatinine is 2.4mg/dLand eGFR is 13. Which of the following opioids can be safely used in her?
questions.explanation: The given lab values in a CKD patient are suggestive of renal failure and remifentanil can be safelyused in renal failure patients.Remifentanil is hydrolyzed by plasma and tissue esterases. The pharmacokinetics and thepharmacodynamics of remifentanil are not altered by renal dysfunction.Option A: Pethidine is metabolized to norpethidine, accumulation of which can lead to CNSexcitatory effects (seizures).Option C: High levels of alfentanil can lead to prolonged action.Option D: Morphine is metabolized to morphine-6-glucuronide which can accumulate leading torespiratory depression.Note: Fentanyl clearance is not altered by renal failure but its plasma protein binding is decreasedwhich can alter the concentration of the free drug. Hence, fentanyl is the second drug of choiceafter remifentanil.

questions.question: A patient who underwent an intra-abdominal surgery is about to receive intraspinal opioidinjection for analgesia. Which of the following drugs should not be used for this purpose?
questions.explanation: Remifentanil should not be used for intraspinal injection.Remifentanil is formulated in combination with glycine. Glycine acts as an inhibitoryneurotransmitter in the spinal dorsal horn that causes a reversible motor weakness when it isinjected intrathecally.For this reason, remifentanil is not approved for spinal or epidural use.

questions.question: Which of the following is the shortest acting opioid?
questions.explanation: The shortest acting opioid is remifentanil with t1/2 of 8-20 minutes.381The rapid metabolism by tissue esterases and rapid clearance results in its ultra short-actingnature.Remifentanil has the fastest onset of action and recovery, making it the opioid of choice indaycare surgery.

questions.question: Which among the following is not included in neuroleptic anesthesia?
questions.explanation: Propofol is not included in neuroleptic anesthesia.Neuroleptic anesthesia includes fentanyl, droperidol, and nitrous oxide.Neuroleptic analgesia includes fentanyl and droperidol.Neuroleptic anesthesia is characterized by analgesia, the absence of clinically apparent motoractivity, suppression of autonomic reflexes, maintenance of cardiovascular stability, and amnesia.QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes due to droperidol have made this techniqueobsolete.

questions.question: You are planning to use a transdermal patch for one of your patients who requirearound-the-clock opioids for his cancer pain. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe?
questions.explanation: Fentanyl is available as a transdermal patch and can be prescribed to this patient. It is mainlyused for chronic pain.Various routes of administration of fentanyl are: intravenous, epidural, spinal,transdermal therapeutic system (transdermal patch and transdermal iontophoresis), oral (buccaltablets, films, lozenges).

questions.question: Which of the following is the drug of choice for rescue analgesia?
questions.explanation: Fentanyl is the drug of choice for providing rescue analgesia.Rescue analgesia involves the use of medications to minimize post-operative pain. Mild pain canbe controlled with oral analgesics but severe pain requires opioids like fentanyl.Fentanyl is preferred over morphine or oxycodone due to its rapid onset of action, lesser incidenceof postoperative nausea, vomiting, and other adverse effects.

questions.question: A 60-year-old man was posted for bronchoscopy under procedural sedation. After theadministration of anesthetic drugs, he developed chest wall rigidity and ineffectivespontaneous ventilation. Attempts at manual ventilation were unsuccessful due to thenon-compliant chest wall. The opioid that is most commonly associated with this conditionis?
questions.explanation: Chest wall rigidity and ineffective ventilation is a classic presentation of 'wooden chest syndrome'.This opioid-induced muscle rigidity is most commonly associated with the use of lipophilicopioids such as fentanyl and its congeners (alfentanil, sufentanil, and remifentanil).Risk factors for wooden chest syndrome:382•Rapid administration of a large dose of fentanyl• Concomitant use of nitrous oxide• Old ageThe clinical presentation can vary from mild hoarseness to chest wall rigidity severe enough toprevent adequate bag-and-mask ventilation.Management of wooden chest syndrome:• Discontinuation of the opioid•Replacement of the opioid with a non-lipophilic version (such as hydromorphone or morphine)for analgesia•Consider naloxone for reversal (you do not want to reverse analgesia on an intubated patientunless absolutely necessary)• Addition of a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker for paralysis•Supportive ventilatory care

questions.question: 374Upon recovering from anesthesia, a patient started feeling cold accompanied by shivering.Which is the opioid indicated to treat this condition?
questions.explanation: Meperidine is commonly indicated for post-anesthetic shivering.It prevents post-anesthetic shivering by lowering the temperature threshold at which shivering istriggered by the hypothalamus.A single dose of 12.5 to 35mg meperidine (pethidine) is effective in the treatment of postanestheticshivering.Infusion-related chills and rigors associated with amphotericin B, aldesleukin, trastuzumab, andalemtuzumab are also managed with meperidine in combination with other agents.

questions.question: A 50-year-old housewife with diabetic nephropathy and receiving dialysis weekly comes toyour clinic with an accidental burn on her left hand. On examination, 2nd-degree burns areseen. Which of the following opioids should not be prescribed to her for analgesia?
questions.explanation: Pethidine (meperidine) should not be prescribed to her as it is contraindicated in patientswith renal failure.In renal failure, there is an accumulation of its metabolite norpethidine which causes excitatorysyndrome consisting of hallucinations, tremors, muscle twitches, and convulsions. Therefore,pethidine is avoided in renal failure patients.Methadone, alfentanil, and fentanyl primarily undergo hepatic metabolism.

questions.question: A woman was administered an intravenous opioid for managing postoperative pain. Within 5minutes, she started developing severe redness and pruritus along the distribution of the veininto which the drug was injected. Which of the following drugs would be responsible for this?
questions.explanation: The clinical findings are suggestive of histamine release, which is common with the use ofmeperidine (pethidine) due to mast cell activation.383Codeine, morphine, and hydromorphone are also associated with histamine release.Fentanyl, alfentanil, and remifentanil do not lead to histamine release.

questions.question: A 16-year-old boy received an intravenous opioid for analgesia. A few minutes later, his heartrate decreased from 72/min to 58/min. Which among the following drugs is least likely to beassociated with this finding?
questions.explanation: Meperidine (pethidine) is least likely to be associated with bradycardia.Intravenous meperidine produces tachycardia as it has a structure similar to atropine. Unlikeother opioids, meperidine causes mydriasis due to its anticholinergic effect.Pentazocine, which is an opioid agonist-antagonist, also produces tachycardia, hypertension, andmydriasis.

questions.question: Which of the following opioids has local anesthetic property?
questions.explanation: The opioid with local anesthetic property is pethidine (meperidine), which is especially seen afterintrathecal administration.Intrathecal pethidine can provide spinal anesthesia for endoscopic urological procedures andsurgery of the lower limb, perineum, and lower abdomen including cesarean section.However, due to low potency and systemic opioid side effects, it is usually not used for thispurpose.

questions.question: Apart from mu-opioid receptors, on which other receptor does tramadol act?
questions.explanation: Tramadol inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, apart from its action on themu-opioid receptor.It is a synthetic codeine analog that is a mu-opioid receptor agonist.Tramadol is a centrally acting analgesic used in the treatment of mild to moderate pain.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding tramadol?
questions.explanation: Tramadol is contraindicated in epileptics.Tramadol is epileptogenic and can cause seizures in predisposed individuals and in those takingmedications like monoamine oxidase inhibitors and neuroleptic drugs.It is a synthetic analogue of codeine and a weak opioid agonist with 1/6000 affinity for μ receptorsas that of morphine.Apart from opioid action, it also inhibits the reuptake of 5HT and NE. Due to non-opioidreceptor-mediated actions, it produces less respiratory depression and less constipation.384

questions.question: A 24-year-old woman requires an intranasal opioid spray for her migraine. Which of thefollowing would you prescribe her?
questions.explanation: Butorphanol is a synthetic opioid available as a nasal spray for use in migraine headaches andpainful conditions.It is used parenterally as an analgesic for moderate to severe pain or as an adjunct to generalanesthesia.Opioids available for intranasal administration are butorphanol and fentanyl.

questions.question: A 40-year-old man, on treatment with fluoxetine for depression, was started on an opioid forsevere neuropathic pain. A few days later he had an episode of syncope and was brought tothe casualty. ECG taken is given below, with QTc = 477 ms. Which of the following drugs ismost likely the cause?
questions.explanation: The given ECG findings show QT prolongation which is associated primarily with the use ofmethadone.In the ECG QTc(corrected QT interval= QT/√RR) is 477ms. Normal QTc is about 440ms. Valuesof more than 440ms in males and 460ms in females are considered to be prolonged. QTprolongation can present as syncope or cardiac arrest.Methadone has additive action with agents known to cause QT prolongation. Serious cardiacarrhythmias including torsades de pointes have been noted with methadone use.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding methadone?

options.C: Rapidly absorbed from GIT and appears in plasma within 30 min of oral administration
options.D: Onset of analgesia is 30-60 min after parenteral and 1-2 h after oral administration377

questions.explanation: Methadone's onset of analgesia is 10-20 minutes after the parenteral route, and 30-60 minutesafter the oral route of administration.Option A: Methadone is a long-acting mu receptor agonist with a plasma half-life of 15-40 hours.Option B: It is an analgesic and used for chronic pain relief.Option C: Absorption from GIT is rapid and appears in plasma within 30 minutes and reachespeak concentrations at around 4 hours.

questions.question: A young man is scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. His medical history is significantfor depression and he is on monoamine oxidase inhibitors for the same. Which of thefollowing opioids can be safely administered to him?
questions.explanation: Morphine can be safely administered as it does not inhibit the neuronal reuptake of serotonin andhence does not trigger serotonin syndrome in patients on MAO inhibitors.Phenylpiperidine series of opioids such as meperidine, tramadol, dextromethorphan,and methadone inhibit the neuronal reuptake of serotonin leading to serotonergic overactivity.This can cause serotonin syndrome in patients receiving monoamine oxidase inhibitors.385

questions.question: A woman sustained multiple fractures in a motorcycle accident. Her physician prescribed anoral opioid for analgesia which is a partial agonist at mu and a full agonist at kappa receptors.Identify the drug given.
questions.explanation: Pentazocine is a partial agonist at mu and a full agonist at kappa receptors.Analgesia produced by pentazocine is predominantly mediated by the к receptor.Pentazocine is a mixed agonist-antagonist opioid agent. It is a full agonist at the к receptor and apartial agonist or weak antagonist at the μ receptor.Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at mu receptors but an antagonist at kappa receptors.

questions.question: A cancer patient is dependent on morphine for pain management. His physician decides toswitch him to buprenorphine. Due to which property he chooses this new drug?
questions.explanation: Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at the mu receptor with a lower intrinsic activity compared tomorphine and hence does not produce withdrawal symptoms in patients with morphinedependence.Buprenorphine is a synthetic thebaine congener and also acts as an antagonist at kappa receptor.It is more potent than morphine at mu receptor but with lower intrinsic activity and ceiling effect.Due to lower intrinsic activity, it has no withdrawal symptoms and can be used in the treatment ofmorphine dependence.

questions.question: An elderly man with bone metastasis is receiving intravenous opioids for pain management.Which of the following drugs can be safely administered to him without a risk of developingrespiratory depression?
questions.explanation: Buprenorphine can be safely administered to this patient because of its ceiling effect onrespiratory depression.Ceiling effect is defined as no further increase in the effect of the drug with a further increment indose, once the ceiling level is reached.Opioid agonist-antagonist compounds produce respiratory depression (and analgesia) with aceiling effect which means increasing the dose further does not produce any further respiratorydepression and may actually result in increased ventilation (due to the predominance ofantagonist actions).Other drugs that show the ceiling effect are:.•ButorphanolNalbuphine•Pentazocine.Respiratory depression with morphine, fentanyl & alfentanyl does not have a ceiling effectbecause they are pure opioid agonists. As the dose increases, respiratory depression also increasesprogressing to respiratory arrest.386Ceiling effectpCO2R- MorphineCeiling effectWDoseBuprenorphineOMARROW

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false?

options.A: Naltrexone is an antagonist at μ receptor
options.B: Meperidine is a pure agonist at μ receptor
options.C: Nalbuphine is an agonist at k receptor
options.D: Butorphanol is an antagonist at k receptor

questions.explanation: Butorphanol is an agonist at к receptor. It may be a partial agonist or antagonist at µ receptor.Pentazocine, butorphanol, buprenorphine, meptazinol, nalorphine, nalbuphine, and dezocine aremixed agonist-antagonist opioids.All opioid agonist-antagonists are μ antagonists and k agonists, except buprenorphine,pentazocine, and dezocine. Buprenorphine, pentazocine, and dezocine are partial agonists at thereceptor.Option A: Naltrexone is a pure antagonist at µ, k, and § receptors.Option B: Meperidine is a pure agonist of both µ and к receptors.u387
